items.standfirst: Stopgap measure fails on 46-52 votes; Karoline Leavitt suggests state supports anarchy as White House continues to blame Democrats for shutdownUS government shutdown day three: Republicans and Democrats make little progress on dealTrump administration freezes $2.1bn in funds for Chicago transit projectsAs the world waits for Hamas’s response to Donald Trump’s peace plan for Gaza, the US president has issued a new deadline for the militant group of 6pm ET on Sunday.Trump, who on Monday gave Hamas “three or four days” to respond to his ultimatum, said they were being given “one last chance”. items.content: White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt cautioned on Friday about the "very tragic consequences" Palestinian militia Hamas would face if the group does not accept US President Donald Trump-led Ga...

items.title: Trump gives Hamas until Sunday to reach a ceasefire agreement and release all hostages
items.standfirst: President Trump posted on social media a stern deadline for Hamas to reach an agreement for a ceasefire and the release of all hostages, including the bodies of those killed since Oct. 7, 2023. CBS News' Willie James Inman reports.
items.content: President Trump posted on social media a stern deadline for Hamas to reach an agreement for a ceasefire and the release of all hostages, including the bodies of those killed since Oct. 7, 2023. CBS News' Willie James Inman reports.

items.title: Hamas has sent out 'mixed messages' in response to Trump's peace plan
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump gave Palestinian Hamas militants until Sunday evening to accept his proposal to end the nearly two-year-old war with US ally Israel in the Gaza Strip. "There have been mixed messages from Hamas", said Noga Tarnopolsky, FRANCE 24's correspondent in Jerusalem. A Hamas military leader from Gaza said he opposed the deal, while the political leadership in Qatar said they wanted to look for gray areas, or places where a compromise could be reached, added Tarnopolsky.
items.content: US President Donald Trump gave Palestinian Hamas militants until Sunday evening to accept his proposal to end the nearly two-year-old war with US ally Israel in the Gaza Strip. "There have been mixed messages from Hamas", said Noga Tarnopolsky, FRANCE 24's correspondent in Jerusalem. A Hamas military leader from Gaza said he opposed the deal, while the political leadership in Qatar said they wanted to look for gray areas, or places where a compromise could be reached, added Tarnopolsky.

items.title: Trump gives Hamas a 'last chance' deadline to agree to a peace plan with Israel
items.standfirst: President Trump said that if Hamas does not agree to the 20-point plan, as presented by Israel and the U.S., then "all HELL, like no one has ever seen before, will break out against Hamas."
items.content: President Trump said that if Hamas does not agree to the 20-point plan, as presented by Israel and the U.S., then "all HELL, like no one has ever seen before, will break out against Hamas."(Image credit: Bashar Taleb)

items.title: Trump sets Sunday deadline for Hamas to agree to his deal for ending the war in Gaza
items.standfirst: U.S. President Donald Trump said Friday that Hamas must agree to a proposed peace deal by Sunday evening, threatening an even greater military onslaught nearly two years into the war sparked by the Oct. 7 attack into Israel. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Jerusalem, Noga Tarnopolsky.
items.content: U.S. President Donald Trump said Friday that Hamas must agree to a proposed peace deal by Sunday evening, threatening an even greater military onslaught nearly two years into the war sparked by the Oct. 7 attack into Israel. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Jerusalem, Noga Tarnopolsky.

items.title: Trump gives Hamas deadline of Sunday to agree to Gaza peace plan

items.content: US president warns militant group that ‘all HELL . . . will break out’ if it does not sign up to his deal

items.title: Egypt foreign minister urges Hamas to accept Trump Gaza plan and disarm
items.standfirst: Hamas reportedly split on response to deal as US president sets Sunday deadline for militant group to replyEgypt and Qatar are working to convince Hamas to accept Donald Trump’s ultimatum to end the war in Gaza, Egypt’s foreign minister has said, as Trump gave a Sunday deadline to reply.Badr Abdelatty said the time had come for Hamas to disarm, and that Israel should be given no excuse to continue its offensive in Gaza, where it killed another 28 Palestinians on Friday. Continue reading...
items.content: Hamas reportedly split on response to deal as US president sets Sunday deadline for militant group to replyEgypt and Qatar are working to convince Hamas to accept Donald Trump’s ultimatum to end the war in Gaza, Egypt’s foreign minister has said, as Trump gave a Sunday deadline to reply.Badr Abdelatty said the time had come for Hamas to disarm, and that Israel should be given no excuse to continue its offensive in Gaza, where it killed another 28 Palestinians on Friday. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump sets Sunday deadline for Hamas to agree to Gaza peace deal
items.standfirst: President Trump said Friday that he is issuing a Sunday evening deadline for Hamas to agree to a U.S. peace proposal, backed by the Israeli government, to end the war in Gaza.
items.content: President Trump said Friday that he is issuing a Sunday evening deadline for Hamas to agree to a U.S. peace proposal, backed by the Israeli government, to end the war in Gaza.

items.title: Trump issues Hamas a Sunday night ultimatum to accept his Gaza peace plan
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump has given Hamas a deadline to agree to his Gaza peace plan. Trump posted on his Truth Social platform on Friday that the agreement must come before Sunday evening or else “all HELL, like no one has ever seen before, will break out”. The plan would place Gaza under a temporary governing committee led by Trump himself and former UK prime minister Tony Blair.
items.content: President Donald Trump has given Hamas a deadline to agree to his Gaza peace plan. Trump posted on his Truth Social platform on Friday that the agreement must come before Sunday evening or else “all HELL, like no one has ever seen before, will break out”. The plan would place Gaza under a temporary governing committee led by Trump himself and former UK prime minister Tony Blair.

items.title: Trump sets new deadline for Hamas to agree Gaza deal with Israel - or face 'all hell'
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump has set a Sunday deadline for Hamas to agree to a deal to end the war in Gaza, warning "all hell" against the group if it does not accept the terms.
items.content: US President Donald Trump has set a Sunday deadline for Hamas to agree to a deal to end the war in Gaza, warning "all hell" against the group if it does not accept the terms.

ai_summary: Trump gave Hamas a Sunday deadline to accept a deal to end the war with Israel.
The proposal seeks immediate ceasefire in exchange for hostage and detainee release.
White House Press Secretary warned of "very tragic consequences" if Hamas rejects the deal.
Karoline Leavitt stated the US is monitoring Russian military actions closely.
The US government is freezing $2.1 billion in funds for Chicago transit projects.

clusters.title: Hegseth says four killed in US strike on alleged drug boat off Venezuelan coast
clusters.neutral_headline: US Strike Near Venezuela Kills Four, Targeting Drug Vessel

items.title: Hegseth says four killed in US strike on alleged drug boat off Venezuelan coast
items.standfirst: Pentagon chief says strike – fourth by US military in recent weeks – targeted boat with ‘substantial amounts’ of drugsThe United States carried out a strike against an alleged drug-trafficking boat on Friday that killed four people, US defense secretary Pete Hegseth said, a day after the Trump administration told Congress it was entering a new “non-international armed conflict” with cartels.The strike, which Hegseth said he directed on Donald Trump’s orders, appears to be at least the fourth in recent weeks. Hegseth gave few details about the boat or the evidence that it was carrying narcotics, other than saying the US had confirmed it was carrying drugs. Continue reading...
items.content: Pentagon chief says strike – fourth by US military in recent weeks – targeted boat with ‘substantial amounts’ of drugsThe United States carried out a strike against an alleged drug-trafficking boat on Friday that killed four people, US defense secretary Pete Hegseth said, a day after the Trump administration told Congress it was entering a new “non-international armed conflict” with cartels.The strike, which Hegseth said he directed on Donald Trump’s orders, appears to be at least the fourth in recent weeks. Hegseth gave few details about the boat or the evidence that it was carrying narcotics, other than saying the US had confirmed it was carrying drugs. Continue reading...

items.title: Hegseth says U.S. strike on boat off Venezuela kills 4 "narco-terrorists"
items.standfirst: U.S. forces carried out a strike on an alleged drug-smuggling boat off the coast of Venezuela on Friday, killing four people, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said.
items.content: U.S. forces carried out a strike on an alleged drug-smuggling boat off the coast of Venezuela on Friday, killing four people, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said.

items.title: Hegseth announces another strike against vessel off Venezuela coast
items.standfirst: Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth announced on social media another strike targeting a vessel allegedly connected to narco-trafficking off the coast of Venezuela. CBS News' Reed Cowan reports.
items.content: Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth announced on social media another strike targeting a vessel allegedly connected to narco-trafficking off the coast of Venezuela. CBS News' Reed Cowan reports.

items.content: According to Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s social media post, the strike killed four men, but it offered no other details on who they were or what organization they belonged to.

items.content: Donald Trump says the boat was carrying enough drugs to kill thousands of people.

Four narco-terrorists were killed, with no U.S. casualties reported. The vessel, operating in international waters, was…

Four narco-terrorists were killed, with no U.S. casualties reported. The vessel, operating in international waters, was…

items.title: US conducts fourth air strike on boat in Caribbean Sea, killing four people
items.standfirst: Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth accused the boat of 'trafficking narcotics' and pledged to continue the air strikes.
items.content: Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth accused the boat of 'trafficking narcotics' and pledged to continue the air strikes.

items.title: Trump officials push claim that US in ‘armed conflict’ with drug cartels
items.standfirst: Administration attempts to justify strikes on alleged Venezuelan drug boats by claiming US under ‘armed attack’The Trump administration is trying to justify strikes on alleged Venezuelan drug boats by advancing a novel legal theory that the US is now in a “non-international armed conflict”, according to a person familiar with a notification to Congress.The notification was provided by senior Pentagon officials as part of an attempt to explain the Trump administration’s legal arguments for the strikes, including a classified briefing to members of the Senate armed services committee on Wednesday. Continue reading...
items.content: Administration attempts to justify strikes on alleged Venezuelan drug boats by claiming US under ‘armed attack’The Trump administration is trying to justify strikes on alleged Venezuelan drug boats by advancing a novel legal theory that the US is now in a “non-international armed conflict”, according to a person familiar with a notification to Congress.The notification was provided by senior Pentagon officials as part of an attempt to explain the Trump administration’s legal arguments for the strikes, including a classified briefing to members of the Senate armed services committee on Wednesday. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The US military conducted a strike on a boat off Venezuela, killing four people.
Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said the strike was ordered by Donald Trump.
The strike is at least the fourth in recent weeks targeting alleged drug trafficking.
Donald Trump stated the boat carried enough drugs to kill thousands of people.
Hegseth announced the strike, but provided no details on the victims or their affiliation.

clusters.title: Israeli military intercepts final aid boat as new flotilla sails to Gaza
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Intercepts Gaza Aid Flotilla, Detaining Activists

items.title: Israeli military intercepts final aid boat as new flotilla sails to Gaza
items.standfirst: The Israeli military intercepted the last boat in an aid flotilla attempting to reach blockaded Gaza on Friday, a day after stopping most of the vessels and detaining some 450 activists including Swedish campaigner Greta Thunberg. Story by Catherine Viette.
items.content: The Israeli military intercepted the last boat in an aid flotilla attempting to reach blockaded Gaza on Friday, a day after stopping most of the vessels and detaining some 450 activists including Swedish campaigner Greta Thunberg. Story by Catherine Viette.

items.title: Why is Israel’s interception of the Gaza flotilla illegal?
items.standfirst: Israel has intercepted the Global Sumud Flotilla sailing to Gaza and detained hundreds of crew members.
items.content: Israel has intercepted the Global Sumud Flotilla sailing to Gaza and detained hundreds of crew members.

items.title: Israeli military intercepts last Gaza Flotilla boat
items.standfirst: Israeli forces intercepted and boarded the Marinette, the last boat of the Global Sumud Flotilla that was still sailing.
items.content: Israeli forces intercepted and boarded the Marinette, the last boat of the Global Sumud Flotilla that was still sailing.

items.title: Final boat of 42-strong pro-Palestinian flotilla intercepted by Israel
items.standfirst: Protest vessel intercepted in the early hours of Friday morning 42.5 nautical miles from the coast of GazaThe last boat of the 42 vessels in the Gaza humanitarian flotillathat sought to breach Israel’s 16-year maritime blockade has been intercepted by Israeli forces.A live stream from the Global Sumud Flotilla (GSF) had late on Thursday evening shown the Polish-flagged sailing boat Marinette still “sailing strong towards Gaza” after the Israeli government claimed to have halted the flotilla carrying about 500 parliamentarians, lawyers and activists including Greta Thunberg. Continue reading...
items.content: Protest vessel intercepted in the early hours of Friday morning 42.5 nautical miles from the coast of GazaThe last boat of the 42 vessels in the Gaza humanitarian flotillathat sought to breach Israel’s 16-year maritime blockade has been intercepted by Israeli forces.A live stream from the Global Sumud Flotilla (GSF) had late on Thursday evening shown the Polish-flagged sailing boat Marinette still “sailing strong towards Gaza” after the Israeli government claimed to have halted the flotilla carrying about 500 parliamentarians, lawyers and activists including Greta Thunberg. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel stops 41 boats in aid flotilla with one ‘still sailing strong’
items.standfirst: Activists from Global Sumud flotilla including Greta Thunberg arrested as final boat is presumed intercepted in Palestinian watersIsrael says it has stopped a pro-Palestinian flotilla carrying aid from reaching Gaza, with its navy intercepting all but one of the vessels trying to breach the blockade.Of the 42 vessels being tracked online by the Global Sumud flotilla (GSF), 41 were listed as having been confirmed or assumed to have been stopped by Israeli forces. Continue reading...
items.content: Activists from Global Sumud flotilla including Greta Thunberg arrested as final boat is presumed intercepted in Palestinian watersIsrael says it has stopped a pro-Palestinian flotilla carrying aid from reaching Gaza, with its navy intercepting all but one of the vessels trying to breach the blockade.Of the 42 vessels being tracked online by the Global Sumud flotilla (GSF), 41 were listed as having been confirmed or assumed to have been stopped by Israeli forces. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel detains Greta Thunberg and others after intercepting an aid flotilla bound for Gaza
items.standfirst: Israeli forces have intercepted an aid flotilla bound for Gaza that was being closely watched around the world, boarding boats and detaining activists including Greta Thunberg who were seeking to break the blockade of the Palestinian enclave.
items.content: Israeli forces have intercepted an aid flotilla bound for Gaza that was being closely watched around the world, boarding boats and detaining activists including Greta Thunberg who were seeking to break the blockade of the Palestinian enclave.

ai_summary: The Israeli military intercepted the last boat in an aid flotilla sailing to Gaza.
The flotilla sought to breach Israel's 16-year maritime blockade of Gaza.
Greta Thunberg was among the activists detained by Israeli forces.
Israel stopped 41 of the 42 vessels in the pro-Palestinian flotilla.
The final boat, the Marinette, was intercepted 42.5 nautical miles from Gaza.

items.title: Apple pulls ICEBlock from App Store following US government pressure

items.content: Developpers deny the Trump administration's accusations that the app put ICE agents at risk, pledging to 'resist'.

items.title: Apple removes app that tracks ICE agents from its App Store
items.standfirst: The developer of the ICEBlock app said the software has been removed from Apple's App Store due to "objectionable content."
items.content: The developer of the ICEBlock app said the software has been removed from Apple's App Store due to "objectionable content."

items.title: Apple Pulls ICE-Tracking Apps on Justice Department’s Urging
items.standfirst: Apple Inc.’s App Store removed ICEBlock and other applications used to report and track sightings of US Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents after the government raised concerns.
items.content: Apple Inc.’s App Store removed ICEBlock and other applications used to report and track sightings of US Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents after the government raised concerns.

ai_summary: Apple removed the ICEBlock app from its App Store after government pressure.
The app tracked sightings of US Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents.
The government raised concerns about the app's potential risks.
The app developer stated the removal was due to "objectionable content."
Apple also removed other apps used to report and track ICE agents.

clusters.title: What we know about the attack
clusters.neutral_headline: Two Killed in Manchester Synagogue Attack

items.title: What we know about the attack
items.standfirst: Two Jewish people were killed in a car and stabbing attack at Heaton Park Hebrew Congregation Synagogue in Manchester on the holiest day in the Jewish religious calendar.
items.content: Two Jewish people were killed in a car and stabbing attack at Heaton Park Hebrew Congregation Synagogue in Manchester on the holiest day in the Jewish religious calendar.

items.title: Why it's critical for progressives to swiftly condemn the attack on a Manchester synagogue
items.standfirst: Members of the Jewish community comfort each other near to the Heaton Park Hebrew Congregation synagogue, in Crumpsall, Manchester, England, on Oct. 2, 2025 after Police reported that two people were killed and three others were seriously injured in a synagogue attack in northern England.
items.content: Members of the Jewish community comfort each other near to the Heaton Park Hebrew Congregation synagogue, in Crumpsall, Manchester, England, on Oct. 2, 2025 after Police reported that two people were killed and three others were seriously injured in a synagogue attack in northern England.

items.title: 2 killed in terrorist attack at Manchester synagogue on Yom Kippur
items.standfirst: Police say a suspect rammed a car into people gathered outside a synagogue in the English city of Manchester, before getting out and stabbing people. The suspect is a 35-year-old British citizen of Syrian descent, according to police. NBC News’ Raf Sanchez reports.
items.content: Police say a suspect rammed a car into people gathered outside a synagogue in the English city of Manchester, before getting out and stabbing people. The suspect is a 35-year-old British citizen of Syrian descent, according to police. NBC News’ Raf Sanchez reports.

items.title: U.K. police declare Manchester synagogue attack 'a terrorist incident'
items.standfirst: Greater Manchester Police Chief Constable Sir Stephen Watson officially declared that the attack at a synagogue in Manchester was a "terrorist incident." The investigation is now being led by counter terrorist police. Two members of Manchester's Jewish community died in the synagogue attack, with others still recovery from their injuries.
items.content: Greater Manchester Police Chief Constable Sir Stephen Watson officially declared that the attack at a synagogue in Manchester was a "terrorist incident." The investigation is now being led by counter terrorist police. Two members of Manchester's Jewish community died in the synagogue attack, with others still recovery from their injuries.

items.title: Two killed in car ramming and stabbing outside U.K. synagogue in a 'terrorist incident'
items.standfirst: Police declared a terrorist incident after two people were killed and three others were seriously injured when a man rammed a car into a crowd and stabbed people at an Orthodox synagogue.
items.content: Police declared a terrorist incident after two people were killed and three others were seriously injured when a man rammed a car into a crowd and stabbed people at an Orthodox synagogue.

ai_summary: Two Jewish people were killed in a car and stabbing attack in Manchester.
The attack occurred at the Heaton Park Hebrew Congregation Synagogue.
Police declared the incident a "terrorist incident" led by counter-terror police.
A 35-year-old British citizen of Syrian descent is the suspect.
Three others were seriously injured in the attack.

clusters.neutral_headline: Church of England Names First Female Archbishop of Canterbury

items.title: Church of England names first female archbishop of Canterbury
items.standfirst: Announcement draws criticism from Anglican churches that oppose female bishops.
items.content: Announcement draws criticism from Anglican churches that oppose female bishops.

items.title: 'Hatred and racism cannot tear us apart,' first woman Archbishop of Canterbury says
items.standfirst: She becomes the first female leader of the Church of England, replacing Justin Welby who resigned over his handling of a safeguarding scandal.
items.content: She becomes the first female leader of the Church of England, replacing Justin Welby who resigned over his handling of a safeguarding scandal.

items.title: Woman is named Archbishop of Canterbury for first time in Church of England history
items.standfirst: Sarah Mullally is the first woman to be named to the post of Archbishop of Canterbury in the history of the Church of England.
items.content: Sarah Mullally is the first woman to be named to the post of Archbishop of Canterbury in the history of the Church of England.

ai_summary: Sarah Mullally is the first woman to be named Archbishop of Canterbury.
The announcement has drawn criticism from some Anglican churches.
She replaces Justin Welby, who resigned over a safeguarding scandal.
She becomes the first female leader of the Church of England.
The new Archbishop stated that hatred and racism cannot tear them apart.

clusters.title: Cyberattack could leave Japan without its most popular beer
clusters.neutral_headline: Cyberattack Threatens Japan's Asahi Beer Supply

items.title: Cyberattack could leave Japan without its most popular beer
items.standfirst: Japan could soon be running out of Asahi, the East Asian nation’s most popular beer, following a devastating cyberattack Monday that has brought its factories to a halt.
items.content: Japan could soon be running out of Asahi, the East Asian nation’s most popular beer, following a devastating cyberattack Monday that has brought its factories to a halt.

items.title: Japan days away from running out of Asahi Super Dry due to cyber attack – reports
items.standfirst: The attack forced the company to halt production at most of its 30 factories nationwide, including those producing its signature beerThe Asahi group, Japan’s biggest brewery, is reportedly just days away from running out of its most popular beer, as it struggles to recover from a cyber-attack that caused a system outage.The ransomware attack, reported on Monday, forced the company to halt production at most of its 30 factories nationwide, including those producing it signature mass-market lager Asahi Super Dry. Continue reading...
items.content: The attack forced the company to halt production at most of its 30 factories nationwide, including those producing its signature beerThe Asahi group, Japan’s biggest brewery, is reportedly just days away from running out of its most popular beer, as it struggles to recover from a cyber-attack that caused a system outage.The ransomware attack, reported on Monday, forced the company to halt production at most of its 30 factories nationwide, including those producing it signature mass-market lager Asahi Super Dry. Continue reading...

items.title: Japan could be hours away from running out of Asahi
items.standfirst: Japan could be hours away from running out of Asahi, the country's most popular beer.
items.content: Japan could be hours away from running out of Asahi, the country's most popular beer.

ai_summary: A cyberattack has halted production at Asahi's factories in Japan.
Japan could soon run out of Asahi Super Dry, its most popular beer.
The attack forced the company to halt production at most of its 30 factories.
The company is reportedly days away from running out of the beer.
The ransomware attack occurred on Monday.

clusters.title: Sean "Diddy" Combs to be sentenced at hearing

items.title: Sean "Diddy" Combs to be sentenced at hearing

items.content: Sean "Diddy" Combs' sentencing hearing is being held three months after he was convicted ​on two prostitution-related charges.

items.title: Sean ‘Diddy’ Combs sentencing live: mogul’s children say he is ‘changed man’; prosecutor says he is casting himself as ‘victim’
items.standfirst: Combs, who could face lengthy prison sentence after being convicted of prostitution charges in July, is expected to address the courtSean ‘Diddy’ Combs expected to speak in courtSean ‘Diddy’ Combs sentencing: what to knowThe prosecution submitted several victim impact statements to the court ahead of sentencing, including one from Ventura.“While the jury did not seem to understand or believe that I engaged in freak-offs because of the force and coercion the defendant used against me, I know that is the truth, and his sentence should reflect the reality of the evidence and my lived experience as a victim” Ventura wrote. Continue reading...

items.title: Sean ‘Diddy’ Combs expected to speak in court as prosecution witness backs out last-minute
items.standfirst: Prospect of disgraced hip-hop mogul getting light sentence dims as judge says Combs hasn’t fully expressed remorseSean ‘Diddy’ Combs sentencing – latest updatesSean “Diddy” Combs was expected to speak in court on Friday afternoon during his criminal sentencing, as one of the prosecution witnesses at the last minute pulled out of a plan to address the hearing.Combs, 55, chose not to testify at his trial earlier this year, when he was convicted by a jury on federal prostitution-related charges. items.title: Debate over Sean "Diddy" Combs sentence
items.standfirst: Sean "Diddy" Combs and his lawyers are pleading for leniency as a judge considers his sentence for two prostitution-related charges. CBS News' Anna Schecter and Caroline Polisi have more.
items.content: Sean "Diddy" Combs and his lawyers are pleading for leniency as a judge considers his sentence for two prostitution-related charges. CBS News' Anna Schecter and Caroline Polisi have more.

items.title: New video of Sean "Diddy" Combs filed in court paints him as family man and role model
items.standfirst: A new video submitted in court as Sean "Diddy" Combs awaits his sentencing portrays the disgraced music mogul as a family man and positive community influence. CBS News' Anna Schecter reports.
items.content: A new video submitted in court as Sean "Diddy" Combs awaits his sentencing portrays the disgraced music mogul as a family man and positive community influence. CBS News' Anna Schecter reports.

ai_summary: Sean "Diddy" Combs' sentencing hearing is being held.
He was convicted on two prostitution-related charges in July.
Combs is expected to address the court during the hearing.
A prosecution witness withdrew from addressing the hearing.
A new video was submitted in court portraying Combs as a family man.

clusters.title: Russian drone kills French photojournalist in eastern Ukraine, military says
clusters.neutral_headline: French Photojournalist Killed in Ukraine Drone Attack

items.title: Russian drone kills French photojournalist in eastern Ukraine, military says
Macron Blames Russia for Death of a French Journalist in Ukraine
French photojournalist Antoni Lallican killed by a drone in Ukraine
items.standfirst: French photojournalist Antoni Lallican, 37, was killed on Friday in eastern Ukraine's Donbas region in a drone attack, according to European journalists' associations. It was the first time a journalist has been killed by a drone in Ukraine since Russia's 2022 full-scale invasion of Ukraine.
items.content: French photojournalist Antoni Lallican, 37, was killed on Friday in eastern Ukraine's Donbas region in a drone attack, according to European journalists' associations. It was the first time a journalist has been killed by a drone in Ukraine since Russia's 2022 full-scale invasion of Ukraine.

items.title: Shutdown has already delayed the jobs report. More critical reports could be held up

items.content: The government's monthly jobs report was not published Friday as a result of the federal shutdown. That's left businesses and policymakers in the dark about the strength of the U.S. job market. (Image credit: Mario Tama)

items.title: US ‘flying blind’ at critical moment for economy, experts warn, with no jobs data amid shutdown
items.standfirst: Data was collected for closely-watched jobs report before shutdown, but Trump officials so far defy calls to publish itCompanies, consumers, policymakers and investors across the US are “flying blind” at a crucial time for the world’s largest economy, a former top official has warned, after Friday’s closely-watched jobs report was not published as a result of the federal government shutdown.The data for the release have already been collected, according to two former heads of the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS). But the Trump administration has so far defied calls to publish the report. Continue reading...
items.content: Data was collected for closely-watched jobs report before shutdown, but Trump officials so far defy calls to publish itCompanies, consumers, policymakers and investors across the US are “flying blind” at a crucial time for the world’s largest economy, a former top official has warned, after Friday’s closely-watched jobs report was not published as a result of the federal government shutdown.The data for the release have already been collected, according to two former heads of the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS). But the Trump administration has so far defied calls to publish the report. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Taylor Swift releases "The Life of a Showgirl" to much fanfare

items.title: Taylor Swift releases "The Life of a Showgirl" to much fanfare
items.standfirst: Taylor Swift's 12th studio album, "The Life of a Showgirl,"​ was released at midnight Friday. Swift wrote and produced the album with Swedish producers Max Martin and Shellback.
items.content: Taylor Swift's 12th studio album, "The Life of a Showgirl,"​ was released at midnight Friday. Swift wrote and produced the album with Swedish producers Max Martin and Shellback.

items.title: Swifties, rejoice! Taylor Swift releases her 12th album, 'The Life of a Showgirl'
items.standfirst: After breaking most music industry records during her "Eras" tour in 2023 and 2024, Taylor Swift is back with the hotly anticipated account of that time in the form of her twelfth studio album. "The Life of a Showgirl" brings in pop princess Sabrina Carpenter and Swedish producers Max Martin and Shellback, who produced Swift's synth pop album "1989" and mega hits "Shake It Off" and "Blank Space". The release coincides with a weekend screening of a behind-the-scenes documentary, where the US star will unveil a new music video from this latest album. FRANCE 24's Olivia Salazar-Winspear tells us more.
items.content: After breaking most music industry records during her "Eras" tour in 2023 and 2024, Taylor Swift is back with the hotly anticipated account of that time in the form of her twelfth studio album. "The Life of a Showgirl" brings in pop princess Sabrina Carpenter and Swedish producers Max Martin and Shellback, who produced Swift's synth pop album "1989" and mega hits "Shake It Off" and "Blank Space". The release coincides with a weekend screening of a behind-the-scenes documentary, where the US star will unveil a new music video from this latest album. FRANCE 24's Olivia Salazar-Winspear tells us more.

ai_summary: Taylor Swift released her 12th studio album, "The Life of a Showgirl," on Friday.
The album was written and produced with Max Martin and Shellback.

The album is a follow up to her "Eras" tour.

clusters.title: Czechs begin voting in election that could return populist to power
clusters.neutral_headline: Czechs Vote in Election, Populist Could Return to Power

items.title: Czechs begin voting in election that could return populist to power
items.standfirst: Billionaire Andrej Babiš hands out doughnuts on first day of voting as polls predict his ANO party will winCzechs have begun voting in an election likely to oust their centre-right government, with polls favouring the populist billionaire Andrej Babiš to return to power on pledges to raise wages and improve growth while reducing aid for Ukraine.The change would boost Europe’s populist anti-immigration camp and could complicate consensus on climate policies in a country where no sitting government has won a second term since 1996. Continue reading...
items.content: Billionaire Andrej Babiš hands out doughnuts on first day of voting as polls predict his ANO party will winCzechs have begun voting in an election likely to oust their centre-right government, with polls favouring the populist billionaire Andrej Babiš to return to power on pledges to raise wages and improve growth while reducing aid for Ukraine.The change would boost Europe’s populist anti-immigration camp and could complicate consensus on climate policies in a country where no sitting government has won a second term since 1996. Continue reading...

items.title: Czech Republic: former PM Babis set for victory in parliamentary elections
items.standfirst: Czechs began voting on Friday in an election likely to oust their centre-right government, with polls favouring populist billionaire Andrej Babis to return to power on pledges to raise wages and lift growth while reducing aid for Ukraine. The change would boost Europe's populist anti-immigration camp and could complicate consensus on climate policies in a country where no sitting government has won a second term since 1996. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Prague, Ian Willoughby.
items.content: Czechs began voting on Friday in an election likely to oust their centre-right government, with polls favouring populist billionaire Andrej Babis to return to power on pledges to raise wages and lift growth while reducing aid for Ukraine. The change would boost Europe's populist anti-immigration camp and could complicate consensus on climate policies in a country where no sitting government has won a second term since 1996. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Prague, Ian Willoughby.

ai_summary: Czechs are voting in an election that could oust the current government.
Polls favor populist billionaire Andrej Babiš to return to power.
Babiš is promising to raise wages and improve growth.
The change could boost Europe's populist anti-immigration camp.
No sitting government has won a second term since 1996.

clusters.title: Treasure hunters discover $1m in silver and gold coins off Florida coast
clusters.neutral_headline: Treasure Hunters Recover $1M in Coins Off Florida Coast

items.title: Treasure hunters discover $1m in silver and gold coins off Florida coast
items.standfirst: Valuables were being transported in 1715 from American colonies when a hurricane wrecked a Spanish fleetHidden beneath the turquoise waters off a stretch of Florida known as the “treasure coast”, a team of divers from a shipwreck salvage company have uncovered exactly that – a load of long-lost Spanish treasure they estimate is worth $1m.More than 1,000 silver and gold coins thought to be minted in the Spanish colonies where Bolivia, Mexico and Peru now sit were uncovered this summer off Florida’s Atlantic coast, 1715 Fleet-Queens Jewels LLC announced this week. Continue reading...

Continue reading...
